definitions.definition: to take in a liquid, gas or other substance from the surface or space around

examples.text: Plants absorb carbon dioxide from the air.
Let the rice cook until it has absorbed all the water.
The cream is easily absorbed into the skin.
Concrete absorbs very little moisture.
Nutrients are absorbed into the bloodstream.

definitions.definition: to take in and keep heat, light, energy, sound, etc. instead of reflecting it

examples.text: Black walls absorb a lot of heat during the day.

definitions.definition: to reduce the effect of a physical impact or movement

examples.text: This tennis racket absorbs shock on impact.
The bats have graphite shafts that absorb the vibration.

definitions.definition: to take something into the mind and learn or understand it

examples.text: It's a lot of information to absorb all at once.
It took me several days to absorb the fact of her death.
They spent a week in Paris just absorbing the atmosphere.
He stood still, absorbing every detail of the scene.
It was great to sit back and absorb the atmosphere.
The information is presented so that it can be readily absorbed.

definitions.definition: to interest somebody very much so that they pay no attention to anything else

examples.text: This work had absorbed him for several years.
Her work absorbed her completely.

definitions.definition: to make something smaller become part of something larger

examples.text: The town absorbs an influx of tourists every summer.
The surrounding small towns have been absorbed into the city.
These committees were gradually absorbed into the local government machine.

definitions.definition: to use up a large supply of something, especially money or time

examples.text: The new proposals would absorb $80 billion of the federal budget.
My work absorbs a great deal of my time.

definitions.definition: to deal with changes, effects, costs, etc.

examples.text: The company is unable to absorb such huge losses.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin absorbere, from ab- ‘from’ + sorbere ‘suck in’.
